Spicy fish koftas

1 tin Tuna
3 medium size potatoes (boiled)
1 large onion chopped fine
2 green chillies chopped fine
2 teaspoons salt
2 teaspoons ground pepper
2 springs of mint leaves chopped fine
1 sprig curry leaves chopped fine
1 egg yolk
Oil for frying
2 eggs beaten
Breadcrumbs for coating

1. Drain fish very thoroughly and get rid of any skin and flake the fish. Remove skin from potatoes and mash it well.
2. In a bowl mix together, the fish, potatoes, chopped onions, chopped green chillies, salt, ground pepper, chopped mint leaves and curry leaves and egg yolk.
3. Once it is mixed thoroughly, shape into small balls, dip each ball in the beaten egg and then roll it in the bread crumbs.
4. Heat the oil in a deep saucepan. The oil should be very hot and then fry the koftas a few at a time quickly. When nicely browned lift them out with a slotted spoon and drain on absorbent paper and serve.
Sarogini's fusion spicy chicken curry

3 tablespoons oil
6 cardamom pods bruised
1 cm piece cinnamon stick
2 tablespoons chopped garlic
2 tablespoons chopped fresh ginger
3 teaspoons chilli powder
2 teaspoons curry powder
2 kg chicken (thighs and drumsticks)
2 Â½ teaspoons salt
2 onions sliced fine
2 cm piece lemon grass (optional)
1 cm piece Pandan leaf (optional)
1 sprig curry leaves
2 tablespoons dark soy sauce
1/4 cup coconut milk

1. Heat the oil in a pan.
2. Add the cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, garlic and ginger and stir well. Add the chilli powder and curry powder. (This should be done on a low heat otherwise the chilli powder can burn).
3. Add the chicken pieces and salt. Mix well so that the chicken pieces are well coated with the other ingredients. Turn the heat down and with a lid on cook the chicken for about 30 minutes.
4. Open the lid and add the sliced onions, lemon grass, pandan leaves, and curry leaves and the soy sauce. Stir and cook for about 15 minutes or until the meat comes off the bone.
5. Add the coconut milk and simmer until the gravy is thick. Dish out and serve with rice or breads.
Prawn curry

500 grams medium sized prawns
3 tablespoons oil
1 tablespoon chilli powder
Â¾ teaspoon salt

1. Clean and wash the prawns leaving the tail on.
2. Heat the oil in a pan
3. Fry the onions until they are caramalised.
4. Lower the heat and add the garlic, curry leaves, chilli powder and salt and cook for a minute or so tirring well. Add the prawns and continue stirring until well coated with the other ingredients. Put a lid on and continue to cook for about 10 minutes
Drumstick (Murunga) curry

5 drumsticks (murungas)
1 teaspoon black mustard seeds
1 sprig curry leaves
2 green chillies slit in the middle
3 tablespoons chilli powder
1 Â½ teaspoons fenugreek seeds
Â¼ cup milk or coconut milk
3 tablespoons oil
1 Â½ teaspoons fenugreek seeds
1 onion chopped
6 cloves garlic sliced lengthwise
1 Â½ teaspoons salt
Â¼ cup water

1. Slightly scrape the skin off the drumsticks and cut the drumstick into 10 cm long pieces and wash them.\n2. Heat the oil in a pan and sautÃ© the drumsticks. Lift them out and fry the mustard seeds and when the mustard seeds begin to pop add the curry leaves, chopped onions, green chillies and the garlic slices and fry for a few minutes on low heat until the onions are caramalised.\n3. Add the chilli powder and then add the sautÃ©ed drumsticks to the masala (chilli mixture) stir well and add the salt, fenugreek and the water. Cover and cook for about 20 minutes or until the drumsticks are cooked. Now add the milk and stir well and cook for about 10 minutes. When well blended remove from stove and serve.
Eggplant and green banana curry

1 eggplant
1 green banana
1 Â½ teaspoons salt
1/4 teaspoon turmeric
1 cup oil
1 large onion sliced fine
4 cloves garlic peeled
1 green chilli sliced in the middle
1 sprig curry leaves
Â¼ teaspoon mustard seeds
Â¼ teaspoon fenugreek seeds
1/4 teaspoon chilli powder
Â¼ cup water
1/3 cup milk

1. Slice eggplant into 2 inch length pieces. Wash the eggplant and mix with1 teaspoon of salt and turmeric and marinate for half an hour. Do the same with the green banana.
2. Heat oil in a pan on high heat and when the oil is hot fry the sliced eggplant a few at a time, until they turn to a golden colour. Drain well on a paper towel. Do this till all the eggplants have been fried. Then fry the green banana slices and drain on a paper towel.
3. Deep fry the sliced onions till they are nice golden brown and add the garlic and green chilli, taking care not to let it burn. Add curry leaves and lower the heat and add the mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds. Drain the fried onions and rest of the fried ingredients and to the fried eggplant and green banana mixture..
4. Drain off the oil from the pan and place the pan over the stove on a low heat. Add the chilli powder and salt and water and bring to the boil. When it has boiled for about 5 minutes add the milk and then add the fried ingredients and give it a good stir. Cook for a further 5 minutes dish out the curry and serve.
Mixed Vegetable Pickel

1 carrot
1 cup of cauliflower florets
1 green Pepper
1 large onion sliced (or 6 shallots peeled and cut into quarters)
11/2 teaspoon mustard seeds
4 cloves garlic peeled
2 cm piece ginger chopped
1/2 cup vinegar
1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder
1/8 teaspoon chilli powder
3 teaspoons salt
2 teaspoons sugar
50 grams Dates chopped
1 small tin pineapple pieces
1 semi-ripe mango chopped

Cut carrot into julienne strips.
Break cauliflower into florets and steam for a few minutes.
Slice the green pepper and onion.
Grind together the mustard seeds, garlic and ginger in a little bit of the vinegar.
In a saucepan, put the ground paste and the balance of the vinegar, turmeric powder, chilli powder, salt and sugar and bring it to a boil and take it off the stove.
In a large bowl mix all the vegetables.
Then pour the boiled dressing and mix well.
When cool mix in the dates, pineapple pieces and the chopped mango and serve.
Crab curry

6 good sized blue swimmer crabs
2 medium onions, finely chopped
6 cloves garlic, finely chopped
2 teaspoon finely grated ginger
10 curry leaves
1 cinnamon stick
1 teaspoon fenugreek seeds
2 teaspoons dark roasted curry powder
1 teaspoon turmeric
2 teaspoon cumin powder
3 teaspoon salt
Chilli powder to suit taste
2 teaspoon tomato paste or 1 large tomato (chopped)
800 ml coconut milk
Juice half lemon or lime
Â½ cup chopped coriander leaves
Oil for cooking

Crabs donât need too much cooking time so the method is pretty simple and should take about 40 minutes to plate. Give the crabs a good bath chilled (salty) water to remove any sand or broken shell. Finely chop the onions, garlic and ginger, and prepare the dry ingredients before you start. Heat the oil in a large sauce pan or wok (youâll need a pretty big pan as crabs take a lot of room, youâll also need to make sure the pan has a lid) and add the onion, garlic, ginger, curry leaves, and sautÃ© the mixture until the onion are soft. Add to this all the dry ingredients, the coconut milk and tomato paste. Cook the mixture on medium heat for 5 minutes stirring constantly. Add the lemon juice and coriander leaves, stir, and then add the crabs and mix through the curry mixture, you can ladle the mix over the crabs to make sure theyâre fully coated (note: there would never be enough curry mix to submerge the crabs in so donât worry as long as they are fully coated). Close the lid and let the crabs steam for 5-7 minutes, before opening, stirring and re-coating, then steaming again for another 5 minutes, theyâre done. The crabs should be a crimson red colour (see the pics of mine above). Serve with white rice and a nice tomato and onion salad. Enjoy!
Ala Kiri Hodi

250g potatoes â boiled and cut into chunks
Â½ onion â sliced
4 cloves garlic â sliced
4 green chilies â cut into small pieces
5 -6 curry leaves
Â½ teaspoon fenugreek (Uluhal)
2 cups coconut milk - little bit thick (mitikiri)
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
Â½ teaspoon chili powder
Â½ teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powe
Salt to taste

Place the coconut milk, onion, garlic, green chilies, curry leaves, fenugreek, all the spices and salt in a medium size sauce pan and mix it all well. Heat the solve on medium heat and place the saucepan on heat for nearly 10 â 15 minutes OR until the curry is boiling. (Continuously stir the curry, if not it will curdle.)When you see the bubbles on the bottom of the saucepan, add boiled potato chunks in to the curry, and let it be on medium heat for another 5 minutes. Taste for salt.
NOTES:
1. If you like you can mix a small piece of cinnamon into the curry.
2. And also if you like you can add 1 â 2 tablespoons Maldives fish into the curry. (NONVEGITERIANS ONLY)
3. Always stir the curry, if not the curry will curdle, and you wonÂ´t get the real taste at all.
4. If you think the curry is too think just add small amount of water. (But potato white curry is tasty when you taste the creaminess of the curry :-))
5. If you like, you can sprinkle little bit of Sri Lankan roasted curry powder on the top of the curry. (Before or after transfer the curry into a serving dish.)
Fish Cutlets

150g canned tuna fish (any fish you like)
150g potatoes â boiled and mashed
1/2onion â finely chopped
4 -5 garlic cloves â finely chopped
1 x 5cm ginger â finely chopped
2 green chilies â finely chopped
4 -5 curry leaves (I didnât have it)
Â½ of a lime or lemon
Â½ teaspoon chili powder
Â½ teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
Â¼ teaspoon paprika powder
1 â 1Â½ tablespoons black pepper powder
3 tablespoons oil

Heat a pan with oil in medium heat.
Then add chopped garlic and ginger. Fry it for nearly 1minute.
Add the onions and fry it till itâs gets light brown.
Now you can add fish or salmon into the pan and and mix it well. Let it cook for nearly 6 - 8 minutes.
Put the heat on law heat and add chili powder, turmeric, pepper and salt, mix the mixture well.
Reduce the heat to low and add mashed potatoes. Mix it well with the fish mixture.
Add lime juice and also taste for salt.
Let it cool nearly 1 hour and now you have make the cutlets to any shape you like. Grab a small handful and slowly form into ball.
Making the Batter OR use the beaten egg:
In a medium bowl, mix the flour, water and pinch of salt together. If you like add pinch of turmeric into the batter.
Deep Frying:
Heat the oil in a large frying pan in medium heat.
When the oil is ready, one by one dip the cutlets in flour batter OR in the beaten eggs and, coated it with bread crumbs well. And deep fry the cutlets till you get a nice golden brown.
Drain the excess oil in kitchen tissues.
NOTES:
1. The most important part when you are forming the cutlet ball, to make sure you don't have any cracks on your cutlet ball. If you have a crack then the cutlet will burst and open when itÂ´s frying.
2. If you donÂ´t like to use the flour batter, you can use the beaten egg for egg washing.
3. If the whole cutlet is not in the oil, make sure you put the oil on the top of the cutlets with a spoon and also remember to turn the sides. If not cutlet will burst from the side which is above the oil.
Egg Rolls

For The Pan Cakes:
2 cups flour
1 egg - (Optional)
1 cup coconut milk â (optional)
Pinch of salt
2 cups cold water
For The Filling
6 hard boiled eggs â cut into hal
Seeni sambola
For Deep Frying:
3 cups of bread crumbs 
1- 2 eggs â beaten
Oil to fry

Making The Pancake Batter:
In a medium bowl, mix the flour and salt together. Then add the egg and 1 cup coconut milk and 1 cup water. Mix it well, if the batter is very thick add little bit water at a time, mix it well and check whether batter is in right consistency for pancakes. (It should be smooth, thin batter, but not like water. )
Making Eggs Rolls:
Heat a small frying pan and little bit of oil with a clean cloth on the pan. When itÂ´s ready pour a large spoon full pancake batter on the pan and cover it. After 5 minutes take the cooked pancake out from the frying pan. 
Keep it on a board, fill it with a full tablespoon of Seeni Sambola and on top of seeni sambola place half of an egg. (Place the Seeni Sambola on the middle of the pancake.) ItÂ´s very important to fold the roll during the pancake is hot.
Fold the two opposite sides into the middle, and from the bottom of the pan cake fold it nicely and tightly. Finely youâll get a nice square shaped roll
Deep Frying:
Heat the oil in a large frying pan in medium heat.
When the oil is ready, one by one dip the rolls in beaten eggs (egg wash the rolls) and, coated it with bread crumbs well. And deep fry the rolls till you get nice golden brown.
Drain it on a paper or kitchen tissues.
NOTE:
1. If you donÂ´t use coconut milk, just add 1 - 1 1/2cups water into the pancake batter.
2. I use cold water, because the batter will be very smooth and no lumps at all :-).
3. If you donât like Seeni Sambola, you can use any filling you like with eggs. (Once I tried with potato filling, but my family didnÂ´t like it very much.)
4. If you donât like to egg wash the rolls, use the same batter which you used to make pancakes. But batter should be little bit thin. (Add Â¼ cup water extra). But crust of the roll will be little bit hard than normal rolls.
Lamb or Mutton Curry

250g Lamb â cut into small chunks
1/2 onion â sliced
4 - 5 garlic cloves â sliced
Small piece of ginger â chopped
1 1/2 teaspoons roasted chili powder
2 teaspoons chili powder
1 Â½ teaspoons black pepper powder
1/2 teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
4 - 5 green chilies â cut into small pieces
5 - 6 curry leaves
1 x 2.5cm cinnamon stick
4 cardamom pods - split
4 cloves â crushed
Â½ teaspoon vinegar
4 - 5 tablespoons oil
Â½ cup coconut milk
1 cup water
2 â 3 tablespoons oil
Salt to taste

In a medium size bowl, mix chili powder, roasted chili powder, black pepper powder, Sri Lankan raw curry powder, turmeric and salt with lamb pieces and keep it aside. the oil in a large saucepan in medium heat.
When oil is hot add garlic and ginger, fry it for 1- 2 minutes, and then add curry leaves and Also clove, cardamom and cinnamon, mix well.
Then add onions and fry nearly 5 â 6 minutes OR until its get slightly light brown.
Now add green chilies.
And also if you like you can add, little bit of turmeric and Â½ teaspoon chili power into the onion mixture just to get a nice colour.
Add the marinated lamb chunks and mix it well with the onion mixture. Fry it for nearly 5 - 6 minutes.(Optional)
If you want, add little bit of oil, especially if you peel off the fat from the meat.
Now add water, stir the curry and keep the curry on medium heat for nearly 15 minutes. When the curry is boiling OR when the water level is Â½ way down, you can add coconut milk and keep it on heat for another 15minutes.
Off the heat and taste for salt.
To get an oil layer on the top of the curry, just keep the curry aside for nearly 5- 10 minutes to cool. (Optional)
NOTES:
1. I used vinegar as a Meat tenderizer. If you canât find vinegar, you can use Gambooge (Goraka) also. 
2. If you donât like the lamb fat, just peel it off, when you cut the meat.
3. When you add onions, add little bit (nearly Â¼ teaspoon) salt also.
4. When you are frying garlic, ginger and also Onions, donât let it burn. Always stir the mixture, so burning chances will be less.
5. If you donât like to fry the meat, you can add water at that stage. 
6. You can add water and coconut milk together if you like. (Sometimes Iâm doing that way also)
7. If you donât like to use coconut milk, of cause you can make this with just water only.
8. If you want thick gravy, just keep the curry on heat for some more time.
Wambatu Moju

250g eggplant â cut into small strips
Â½ red onion â cut into cubes
10 green chilies â cut it from the middle (optional)
2 â 3 cloves of garlic
2.5cm x 1 piece of ginger
20 â 25 dried sprats
8 â 10 curry leaves
1 tablespoon coriander power
1 Â½ mustard seeds
Vinegar
2 â 3 teaspoons Sugar
Oil to fry
Salt to taste

Heat the oil in a large frying pan in medium heat.
When oil is ready, deep fry the eggplant strips till it gets little bit dark brown in color on both sides.
Drain it on a paper or kitchen tissues to remove excess oil. 
Now add onions and green chilies and fry it for nearly 5 â 10 minutes and Drain it on a paper or kitchen tissues to remove excess oil.
Finally fry the dried sprats till you get a nice golden color and Drain it on a paper or kitchen tissues to remove excess oil.
Now with the help of a blender or a mortar and pestle (Wangediya) minced the ginger and garlic. When you get a fine paste now add mustard into the ginger garlic paste and minced it till the mustard seeds vanished. You will get a fine paste of ginger, garlic and mustard. 
Now place the paste in a small bowl, and add coriander power, sugar, salt and vinegar and stir the mixture till sugar is dissolve.
Fried Rice

6 cups cooked basmati rice
2 cups carrot â julienne
2Â½ cups leeks â julienne
1 cup beans â small pieces
1 cup green peas â 1 cup
2 medium size onions - sliced
3 cloves of garlic - chopped
1.5cm x 1 ginger - chopped
70g butter
2 teaspoons soy sauce
2 teaspoons oyster sauce
1 teaspoon sesame oil 
2 eggs â beaten (optional)
Black pepper power
Salt to taste

Heat the wok in medium heat and add Â½ amount butter into the wok. When butter is ready add ginger garlic mix and keep it for 2 â 3 seconds, then add the onions and little bit of salt and let it cook for nearly 2 - 3 minutes.
When onions are ready, add the carrot with little bit salt and mix it well. Let it cook for nearly 5 minutes or you can see the colour difference when the carrot is cooked. At that point, add the leeks and let is be there for 2 minutes. And then add beans and green peas also. Mix it well. Let it cook for nearly 2 â 3 minutes.
Then add the beaten eggs and make scramble eggs when itâs cooked mix it well with the vegetables.
Reduce the heat into low and then add all the sauces into the wok, mix it well.
Now you can add rice and mix it well.
Taste for salt.
NOTES:
1. Carrot and onions will cook quickly, in that case you have to add little bit salt with those two ingredients to get the nice taste.
2. If you use grated carrot, during the cooking time, large amount of water will come out from carrot, and the fried rice wonât taste good. So what Iâm saying is, if you want to taste nice fried rice donât use grated carrot. 
3. When you are adding eggs into the vegetable mix, first scramble the eggs in a separate pan or just keep the vegetables aside in the same pan. If you do it like that, in the end youâll get a nice colour in the fried rice. If not the eggs will coated in the vegetables and fried rice wonât be colourful rice.
4. If you like you can use Maggi or Knorr soup cube in the fried rice. If you are using, with little bit hot water make a paste and add it when you are adding sauces into the vegetable mix.
5. If you are making large amount of fried rice, mix them both in a separate pan with small portions.
White Chicken Curry

500g chicken â cut into small chucks
Â½ onion â sliced
3 cloves of garlic â sliced
4 â 5 curry leaves
Â½ teaspoon fenugreek (Uluhal)
1 teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powder
Â¼ teaspoon Chili powder
Â½ teaspoon Turmeric
1 Â½ cups coconut milk
350ml water
Salt to taste

Place these all ingredients (onions, garlic, fenugreek, curry leaves, turmeric, chili powder, Sri Lankan raw curry powder and salt) in a medium size saucepan.
Then add the chicken pieces into the saucepan and mix it well.
Then add water and Â½ cup of coconut milk and mix it well with chicken mixture.
And now keep the saucepan on high heat for nearly 15 minutes.
Then stir the curry and keep it on heat for nearly another 15- 20 minutes.
When the water level has gone down, itâs the time to the rest of the coconut milk into the chicken, and slowly mixes it well.
Reduce the heat and keep the saucepan on heat for another 15 minutes or the amount of the gravy you want. Taste for salt.
(Stir the curry while you are cooking. If you donât, the coconut milk will get curdle.)
NOTES:
1. If you cut chicken into small chunks, the benefits are, chicken will cook quickly, it will adsorb the spices well and at last the taste is very good.
2. Firstly chicken should cook in the second time milk. (Diya kiri)
3. After you added the coconut milk for the second time, if you keep the curry on very low heat for nearly Â½ hour, you will get a nice yellowish oil layer on the top of the chicken curry.
4. If you like, you can sprinkle little bit of Sri Lankan roasted curry powder on the top of the curry. (Before or after transfer the curry into a serving dish.)
Purawapu Mallu Miris

2 paprika
2 onions â sliced
3 cloves of garlic â sliced
Â½ cup Maldives fish
1 teaspoon chili powder
1Â½ teaspoons chili pieces
1 teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
3 â 4 teaspoons lime juice
Â½ cup coconut milk
Salt to taste

Firstly cut out the steams of paprika and clean the inside of paprika. (Take out the seeds, and get free space to fill the mixture.)
Then with a folk just make some tiny holes all over the paprika, especially on the top and bottom. Keep it aside.
Now in a medium size bowl mix all the ingredients together (onion, garlic, Maldives fish, chili powder, chili pieces, Sri Lankan Curry Powder, turmeric and salt) except lime juice and coconut milk. 
After you mix all the ingredients well, add lime juice and mix it again.
Take out nearly 2 â 3 tablespoons from the onion mixture and keep it aside.
Now fill the paprika with onion mixture, till the paprika is full.
In a medium size saucepan, add the onion mixture that you kept aside, and also add 1/4 very small amount of all the spices we used for the onion mixture and also salt to taste.
Then pour the coconut milk and, let it get warm on medium heat.
When the coconut milk is hot, adds the filled paprika and coved the saucepan with the lid. Remember to turn the paprika upside down for every 5 â 10 minutes.
When th paprika is soft And there is only little bit thic gravy, itÂ´s time to take the saucepan out from the heat.
Taste for salt.NOTE:
1. If you like to eat seeds, just add the seeds you took out from the paprika into the onion mixture.
2. If you are using capsicums no need to do this step. (IÂ´m doing this step because paprika is very thick, with this step itÂ´s easy to make it soft while cooking.)
3. If you donât like to add spices again into the curry, just forget that step.
4. If you feel, that coconut milk is not enough to get paprika soft, just cover the saucepan and put the heat medium to law.
5.Cooking time is depending on the size, hardness and also the holes you marked on the paprika.
6. After itÂ´s cooked, there will be some gravy, itÂ´s because of onions. From onions water will come and it will get mix with Coconut milk gravy.
Ala Thel Dala

3 boiled potatoes â cut into chunks 
1 onion â sliced
3 â 4 garlic cloves - sliced
4 â 5 teaspoons Maldive fish â optional
1 Â½ teaspoons mustard seeds
2 tablespoons lime juice
2 teaspoons chili pieces
Â½ teaspoon chili powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
4 â 5 tablespoons oil
1x1.5cm cinnamon piece
5 â 6 curry leaves
salt to taste

In a medium bowl, mix all the ingredients (onion, garlic,Maldive fish, lime juice, chili pieces, chili powder, turmeric and salt) except the potatoes and oil. Heat a pan in medium heat and when itÂ´s hot add the oil. When oil is ready add mustard seeds and let it pop up (nearly 2 â 4 seconds), then add cinnamon and curry leaves and let it fry for 1 â 2 minutes. then add the onion mixture and mix it well with oil. Keep it on heat for 5 minutes. After that mix it again and keep it again for another 5 minutes.
When the onion mixture is nice brown and also you can smell a nice smell, thatÂ´s the time you have to add potatoes into onion mixture. Mix onions and potatoes well but donÂ´t break potatoes into small pieces. Keep it on heat nearly 2 â 3 minutes. Taste for salt.
NOTE:
1.If you donÂ´t have Maldive fish, you can use dried prawns also. Break it to small pieces.
2.If you want you can add lime juice at the end, no problem you can do it that way also.
Srilankan style Pork Curry

650g pork â cut into small chunks
1 onion â sliced
3 garlic cloves â sliced
Small piece of ginger â chopped
3 teaspoons chili powder
2 teaspoons black pepper powder
1 teaspoon Sri Lankan raw curry powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
6 - 8 curry leaves
1 x 2.5cm cinnamon stick
4 cardamom pods - split
4 clove â crushed
3 tablespoons oil
3 cups water
Salt to taste

In a medium size bowl, mix chili powder, black pepper powder, Sri Lankan raw curry powder, turmeric and salt with pork pieces and keep it aside.
Heat the oil in a large saucepan in medium heat.
When oil is hot add garlic and ginger, fry it for 1- 2 minutes.
Then add onions and fry it till itâs gets light brown.
Now you can add all the dry spices and fry it nearly for 2minutes. 
Add the marinated pork chunks and fry it for nearly 15 minutes on both sides.
After itâs fried, add water, stir the curry and keep the curry on high heat for nearly 15 minutes.
Now the gravy should be little bit thick, so change the heat into medium and again keep it for nearly 15 minutes
Off the heat and taste for salt.
NOTE:
1. Itâs good if you can keep the pork chunks after mixing with spices (to marinate) nearly 15 â 20 minutes.
2. If you donât like to fry the onions (Temper the onions and garlic with dry spices), you can add all the ingredients and mix together, and cook. (Can ski the first 5 steps.)
3. Also if you donât like to fry the pork chunks, just skip the 6th step.
Wambatu Salad

1 eggplant â cut into small strips
1 onion â sliced
3 â 4 green chilies â optional
1 salad leaf â optional
1 teaspoon black pepper powder
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
2 - 3 tablespoons lime juice
Oil to deep fry
Salt to taste

Get ready a medium size water bowl mix with turmeric and Â¼ teaspoon salt. 
Wash the eggplant and cut it into small strips, and put the strips into turmeric mix water bowl.
While you are cutting the eggplant, you can heat the oil in a large frying pan in medium heat.
When oil is ready, deep fry the eggplant strips till it gets little bit dark brown in colour on both sides.
Drain it on a paper or kitchen tissues to remove excess oil. 
Now chopped the green chilies and salad leaf, and keep it aside.
In large bowl, place the deep fried eggplant strips, onions, chopped green chilies and salad leaf, black pepper powder and salt. 
Mix it well, and finally add the lime juice and mix it again.
NOTE:
We are placing the eggplant strips in turmeric andsalt mix water bowl, so it wonÂ´t change the colour of the eggplant strips.
Kaha Bath

1Â½ cup Basmati rice - washed
1 onion â sliced
5 cloves of garlic â chopped
3 teaspoons margarine or butter
Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
5 cloves - crushed
5 cardamoms - crushed 
2.5cm cinnamon stick 
1.5 cups water
Salt to taste

Heat the saucepan on medium heat and add 2 teaspoons margarine.
When margarine is melted add onions, garlic and Â½ teaspoon salt, fry it for nearly 10 minutes or till you gets the little golden brown.
Then add the rest of the margarine, 1/2 cup water, turmeric, cloves, cardamoms, cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Mix it well and add the rice and again put 1 cup of water.
Cover the saucepan and keep it for nearly 10 minutes or till the rice is cooked.
NOTE:
1. When you are adding dry spices (cloves, cardamoms, cinnamon) into the rice, you can make a bag with piece of a cloth, and tie it tightly. Then add that cloth bag to the saucepan. When the rice is cooked, you can just remove the spices bag.
2. If you can find black pepper corns, add Â½ teaspoon with the turmeric, it will give you a good taste and also a nice look.
